title: Four Taste Groups
fact: In addition to the taste groups of bitter, sour, salty, and sweet, your tongue can also sense a taste group known as "umami" which is a savory and meaty taste.

title: Food Before Swimming
fact: Eating shortly before swimming does not increase the risk of experiencing muscle cramps. There is a correlation between alcohol and drowning, however.

title: Sugar Makes Kids Hyper
fact: Nope, sugar doesn't cause hyperactivity. Several studies have shown no difference in behavior between children given sugar-full or sugar-free diets, even for sensitive kids.

title: Left and Right Brain
fact: Mental abilities are not absolutely separated into the left and right side the brain. In fact, if one hemisphere is damaged at an early age, the other can take over.

title: 8 Daily Glasses of Water
fact: Eight glasses of water a day are not always needed. In reality, it varies by weight, activity level, clothing,  heat, and humidity. Plus, you can get water from food, too.

title: Gum Digests Over Years
fact: No, it doesn't take seven years to digest. The truth is: Chewing gum is mostly indigestible, and passes through the digestive system at the same rate as other matter.

title: Alcohol Warms
fact: Alcoholic drinks create the sensation of warmth by making blood vessels dilate and stimulating nerve endings in the skin. It can actually make your body temperature fall.

title: Vaccines Cause Autism
fact: No, vaccines do not cause autism. Although fraudulent research claimed a connection, repeated new studies ended in failure, and the original paper was dismissed.

title: Learning Styles
fact: All humans learn in simialr ways. There is no evidence that people have different learning styles, nor that different teaching styles improve information retention.

title: Dairy Builds Up Mucus
fact: Drinking milk or consuming other dairy products does not increase mucus production. They don't need to be avoided by those with the flu or cold congestion.

title: Vitamin C  Against Colds
fact: Vitamin C does not prevent the common cold, although it may have a protective effect during intense cold-weather exercise and may reduce the duration of colds.

title: Cracking Knuckles
fact: Cracking one's knuckles in good health doesn't cause arthritis or other issues. The cracking sound comes from a gas bubble forming when the joints separate.

title: Taste Zones
fact: There are no distinct "zones" for sweet, bitter, sour, and salty on your tongue. All different tastes can be detected on all parts of the tongue by all taste buds.

title: Diet Detoxification
fact: There is a common myth that specific diets aid "detoxification" and can remove substances from your body. In reality, your liver and kidney do it automatically.

title: Alcohol Kills Brain Cells
fact: While it's certainly not a health food, alcohol does not necessarily kill brain cells. This is different for alcoholics who can lose brain cells from withdrawal (excitotoxicity).

title: Vegans Lack Protein
fact: A vegetarian or vegan diet can provide enough protein for adequate nutrition and in most cases does. However,  vitamin B12 supplementation can be required.

title: Sex Hurts Performance
fact: There is no scientific basis for the belief that having sex in the days before a sporting event reduces performance. In fact, sex can increase testosterone which could help.

title: 10% of Your Brain
fact: We don't only use only ten percent of our brains. In reality, a small minority of neurons in the brain are actively firing at a given time, but the others have important functions, too.

title: Waking Sleepwalkers
fact: Sleepwalkers can get confused when woken, but not harmed. In fact, if you let them sleepwalk they can lose their balance and fall. They're not zombies, wake them!

title: Rust Causes Tetanus
fact: Since the same (anoxic) conditions that harbor tetanus bacteria (Clostridium tetani) also promote rusting of metal, the two have incorrectly become synonymous.

title: Drowning is Visible
fact: Drowning is often inconspicuous to onlookers. In many cases, raising the arms and screaming are impossible due to the instinctive drowning response.

title: Veins Have a Blue Color
fact: Hemoglobin gives blood its red color. Deoxygenated blood has a deep red color, and oxygenated blood has a cherry-red color. Skin light scattering causes a blue appearance.

title: Vacuums Explode Bodies
fact: It's perfect for movies, but not true. Vacuums and de-compression do not cause the body to explode or internal fluids to boil. Instead, they lead to a slower death from hypoxia.

title: We Have Five Senses
fact: In addition to sight, smell, taste, touch, and hearing, humans can sense at least 20 things including balance, acceleration, position, pain, temperature, pressure, and thirst.

title: Water Causes Wrinkles
fact: "Water wrinkles" are not caused by skin absorption. They are caused by the nervous system, which triggers localized vasoconstriction (narrowing) in response to wet skin.

title: Shaving Thickens Hair
fact: Shaving does not cause hair to grow back thicker, denser, or darker.  In reality, shaving cuts hair tips and causes them to be more blunt, making them feel coarser.

title: Conditioners Repair
fact: Hair products cannot actually "repair" split ends and damaged hair. They can prevent damage from occurring, and they smooth the cuticle like glue so that it looks repaired.

title: Hair Grows After Death
fact: Hair and fingernails do not continue to grow after a person dies. Rather, the skin dries and shrinks away from the bases of hairs and nails, giving the appearance of growth.

title: Food
fact: Despite being associated with Chinese cuisine, they were invented in Japan and introduced to the US by the Japanese. The cookies are extremely rare in China.

title: Chinese Fortune Cookies
fact: Despite being associated with Chinese cuisine, they were invented in Japan and introduced to the US by the Japanese. The cookies are extremely rare in China.

title: Heat Removes Alcohol
fact: A study showed that after 2 hours of cooking, 10% of the original alcohol was still present. The amount wasn't enough to cause intoxication, though.

title: Espresso vs. Coffee
fact: A standard cup of brewed coffee has more caffeine than a single shot of espresso. In fact, the much larger volume of regular Joe offsets the caffeine to water ratio.

title: MSG Headaches
fact: "Chinese restaurant syndrome" is largely a myth. There is no large study that shows that MSG triggers migraines. Some early studies hint at potentials for sensitivity.

title: Spicy Food Causes Ulcers
fact: Another popular misconception. Evidence does not support a significant role for spicy food or coffee in the development of peptic ulcers in healthy people.

title: Metal Breaks Microwaves
fact: Placing metal inside a microwave oven does not damage the oven's electronics. But it's still not safe! Electrical arching makes metal hot and can harm you.

title: Carrots Improve Vision
fact: This myth originated in World War 2. While carrots are healthy, they don't give you supervision. They can help people with vitamin A deficiency see better, though.

title: Twinkies Never Expire
fact: Twinkies have a shelf life of approximately 45 days and only remain on the shelf for about ten days. In any case, they won't stay fresh and edible for decades.

title: Animals
fact: Dogs do not sweat by salivating. They have sweat glands and sweat mainly through their footpads. However, dogs do regulate their body temperature through panting.

title: Sweating Dogs
fact: Dogs do not sweat by salivating. They have sweat glands and sweat mainly through their footpads. However, dogs do regulate their body temperature through panting.

title: Elephant Graveyards
fact: Older elephants that are near death do not leave their herd and instinctively direct themselves toward a specific location known as an elephants' graveyard to die.

title: Toads Cause Warts
fact: Humans cannot catch warts from toads or other animals. In fact, the bumps on a toad are not even warts. Human warts are caused by the papillomavirus.

title: Seeing Red
fact: Bulls are not enraged by the color red, used in capes by matadors. Cattle are dichromats so red does not stand to them. Instead, the matador looks like a threat.

title: Blind Bats
fact: Bats are not blind. While about 70 percent of bat species, mainly in the microbat family, use echolocation to navigate, all bat species have eyes and are capable of sight.

title: Head in the Sand
fact: Ostriches do not stick their heads in the sand to hide from enemies. This misconception was probably incorrectly promulgated by Pliny the Elder (23–79 CE).

title: Frog in Hot Water
fact: Frogs die immediately when cast into boiling water, rather than leaping out. Frogs will attempt to escape cold water that is slowly heated past their critical thermal maximum.

title: Alpha Wolves
fact: There is no such thing as an "alpha" in a wolf pack. Wolf packs operate like human families: there is no sense of rank, parents are in charge, and none are overthrowing elders.

title: Bumblebees Can't Fly
fact: The flight mechanism and aerodynamics of the bumblebee are quite well understood, despite the urban legend that calculations show that they can't fly.

title: Earwigs in Your Ears
fact: Earwigs don't climb into ear canals. Entomologists suggest that the name is a reference to the appearance of unfolded hindwings, which resemble human ears.

title: Short-Lived Flies
fact: Houseflies have a lifespan of 20 to 30 days, not 24 hours. Some species of mayflies do have the lifespan attributed to the housefly. Housefly maggot hatch within 24 hours.

title: Swallowing Spiders
fact: The urban legend that one swallows lots of spiders during sleep in one's life has no basis in reality. A sleeping person causes noise and vibrations, making spiders flee.

title: Science
fact: Flowering sunflowers point in one fixed direction (often east) all day long. Young sunflowers, before growing flower heads, do track the sun (through heliotropism), then stay fixed.

title: Sunflowers Face the Sun
fact: Flowering sunflowers point in one fixed direction (often east) all day long. Young sunflowers, before growing flower heads, do track the sun (through heliotropism), then stay fixed.

title: 50-50 Coin Flip
fact: A coin has a slightly higher chance of landing on the side that was facing up before the flip. Students at Stanford University recorded thousands of flips. The result? 49-50!

title: Yellow Sunshine
fact: The Sun's color is white, when viewed from space or when high in the sky. Atmospheric scattering renders the Sun's appearance yellow, red, orange, or magenta.

title: Spinning Toilet Water
fact: Water does not consistently drain in a counter-clockwise vortex in basins in the Northern Hemisphere and clockwise in the Southern due to the Coriolis effect.

title: Lightning Strikes Twice
fact: The idea that lightning never strikes the same place twice is one of the best-known superstitions. Lighting Empire State Building in New York City about 100 times per year.

title: Great Wall of China
fact: The Great Wall of China is not, as is claimed, the only human-made object visible from the Moon or from space. What can be seen are the many city lights at night.

title: Sun and Seasons
fact: Seasons are not caused by the Earth being closer to the Sun in the summer than in the winter. Seasons are actually caused by Earth's 23.4-degree axial tilt.

title: Burning Hot Meteorites
fact: Meteorites are often cold when they reach the Earth's surface. In fact, many meteorites are found with frost on them. As they enter the atmosphere, they're still below freezing.

title: Genetic Determinism
fact: Not every aspect of the biology of an organism can be predicted from genes. Some behavior is genetically-based, others from learning and epigenetic inheritance.

title: Theory of Evolution
fact: The word theory in "theory of evolution" does not imply any scientific doubt regarding its validity. The words theory and hypothesis have specific meanings in a scientific context.

title: A Gene for X
fact: In early genetics, it was assumed that there is "a gene for" a range of characteristics (e.g. "gay gene"). However, gene expression is much more complex and subtle.

title: Glass Slowly Flows
fact: Glass does not flow at room temperature. Old glass looks like it flowed over the centuries. However, this unevenness is due to the manufacturing processes used at the time.

title: Black Holes
fact: Black holes are not inter-dimensional portals. Instead, they're hugely dense objects with gravitational pull. They're "cosmic vacuum cleaners" that sucks in everything.

title: Evolved From Chimps
fact: Humans did not evolve from either of the living species of chimpanzees. Humans and chimpanzees actually evolved from a common ancestor (CHLCA) 8 mil. years ago.

title: Dropped Pennies Kill
fact: A penny dropped from the Empire State Building will not kill a person or crack the sidewalk (but can harm). It falls at "only" 30–50 miles per hour from any height. Don't try it!

title: Photographic Memory
fact: There is no scientific evidence for the existence of "photographic" memory. Outlier memory is often the result of using mnemonic devices rather than a natural capacity.

title: Salt Water Boils Quicker
fact: Salt doesn't make water boil quicker, in fact, it does the opposite! In reality, so called "Boiling Point Elevation" happens, making the salt water mixture take longer to heat.

title: Multiple Personalities
fact: Schizophrenia is not the same as dissociative identity disorder (having multiple personalities). The confusion comes misinterpreting the Greek words for "split" and "mind."

title: Oil Unsticks Food
fact: Adding oil to pasta doesn't make it stick less. In fact, it will only make the pasta more slippery and therefore sauces run off. Plus, you add a bunch of extra calories.

title: Lightweight Cloud
fact: Despite their appearance, clouds are made of water. The average cumulus cloud weighs about 1 million pounds, while a big storm cloud can exceed 2 billion pounds.

title: Earth's First Continent
fact: Pangea wasn't the original supercontinent. It was the last in a series of seven, which joined and split at regular intervals. The first was Vaalbara, 3.6 billion years ago.

title: Everything Dies
fact: While most species die, some get lucky. Turritopsis dohrnii (the "immortal jellyfish") can bounce between a sexually immature stage and adulthood, again and again.

title: Bananas Grow on Trees
fact: Although it's often called a “banana tree” the stem of the banana plant does not contain any wood. In fact, it is actually a herbaceous plant (i.e. an herb). A very big herb…

title: Chameleons Camouflage
fact: Color change in chameleons rarely is used for camouflage. Instead, it's most commonly used for social signaling and to regulate their body temperature.

title: History
fact: Vomiting was not a regular part of Roman dining. In ancient Rome, the architectural feature called a vomitorium was an entranceway for a stadium, not a  room used for purging.

title: Vomiting Romans
fact: Vomiting was not a regular part of Roman dining. In ancient Rome, the architectural feature called a vomitorium was an entranceway for a stadium, not a  room used for purging.

title: People Lived to 30
fact: Life expectancy in the Middle Ages and earlier was lower than today, but not 30 years. The average was skewed by high infant mortality. People often lived to 65 and older.

title: Viking Horns
fact: There is no evidence that Vikings wore horned helmets.  The image stems from a scenography of the Der Ring des Nibelungen opera by Wagner and stuck.

title: Medieval Torture
fact: Iron maidens weren't invented in the Middle Ages or used for torture. They were pieced together in the 18th century from artifacts to sell more exhibition tickets.

title: Chastity Belts
fact: Modern historians have found no evidence that chastity belts were invented in the middle ages. Most artifacts turned out to be 20th century fakes to discourage masturbation.

title: Flat Earth
fact: Medieval Europeans did not believe the Earth was flat. Since the ancient Greek philosophers Plato and Aristotle, belief in a spherical Earth was universal among intellectuals.

title: Columbus' America
fact: Columbus never reached any land that now forms part of the mainland United States of America. Most of the landings were on the beaches of the Carribean.

title: Pilgrims Wore Black
fact: The settlers of the Plymouth Colony did not wear all black (and didn't have hats with buckles). Fashion was based on the Elizabethan era: Colorful doublets, jerkins, and ruffs.

title: Marco Polo's Pasta
fact: Marco Polo did not import pasta from China. Instead, durum wheat pasta was introduced by Arabs from Libya, during their conquest of Sicily in the late 7th century.

title: Salem Witch Trials
fact: The falsely accused at the Salem witch trials were not burned at the stake; about 15 died in prison, 19 were hanged, and one was pressed to death. Still, very sad.

title: Let Them Eat Cake
fact: Marie Antoinette did not say "let them eat cake" when she heard that the French peasantry was starving. The phrase was first published by Rousseau.

title: Washington's Teeth
fact: George Washington did not have wooden teeth. His dentures were made of gold, hippopotamus ivory, lead, and animal teeth (including horse and donkey). Bling, bling.

title: July 4, 1776
fact: The signing of the United States Declaration of Independence did not occur on July 4, 1776. After the Second Continental Congress voted on July 2, the signing was on August 2, 1776.

title: Napoleon Was Short
fact: At 5'7", Napoleon Bonaparte was actually  taller than the average Frenchman of his time. The nickname le Petit Caporal (The Little Corporal) was a term of affection.

title: Cowboy Hats
fact: Cowboy hats were not popular in the Western American frontier, with derby or bowler hats being the headgear of choice. Heavy marketing after the Civil War changed that.

title: New World, New Name
fact: Immigrants' last names were not Americanized (voluntarily, mistakenly, or otherwise) upon arrival at Ellis Island. There was no law to record immigrant names at that time.

title: War of the Worlds
fact: There was no widespread outbreak of panic across the United States in response to Orson Welles' 1938 radio adaptation of H.G. Wells' The War of the Worlds.

title: Einstein Flunked Math
fact: Albert Einstein did not fail math classes.  Upon seeing a column making this claim, Einstein said: "Before I was fifteen I had mastered differential and integral calculus."

title: "Ich bin ein Berliner"
fact: JFK's words "Ich bin ein Berliner" are standard German for "I am a Berliner." An urban legend says that Berliner is translated to jelly donut and that Berliners were amused.

title: The Red Telephone
fact: The Moscow–Washington hotline was never a telephone line, nor at the White House. It is a Moscow-Pentagon link that used teletype, then fax, and since 2008 secure email.

title: Society
fact: Entrapment law in the U.S. does not require police officers to identify themselves as police during stings or undercover work. Plus, police officers may lie during such work.

title: Yes, I'm a Cop
fact: Entrapment law in the U.S. does not require police officers to identify themselves as police during stings or undercover work. Plus, police officers may lie during such work.

title: Chubby Buddha
fact: The historical Buddha was not obese. The "chubby Buddha" or "laughing Buddha" is actually based on a jolly 10th-century Chinese folk hero by the name of Budai.

title: 24 Hours Missing
fact: It is not necessary to wait 24 hours before filing a missing person report. If there is evidence of violence or an unusual absence, police wants to act quickly.

title: Sign Language
fact: Aside from the Pidgin International Sign, each country generally has its own, native sign language, and some have more than one (although many are similar).

title: Edison's Light Bulb
fact: Thomas Edison did not invent the light bulb. He did, however, develop the first practical light bulb in 1880 (employing a carbonized bamboo filament).

title: Ford's Assembly Line
fact: Henry Ford did not invent the automobile (Karl Benz did) or the assembly line. But Ford improved the process, through engineering and by sponsoring his employees' work.

title: Cameras Prevent Crime
fact: Despite numerous studies, there is little evidence that cameras directly reduce crime rates. Instead, they are often used to detect and prosecute crime after the fact.

title: Toilet Door Handles
fact: While 30% of people don't wash their hands, door handles have fewer bacteria than other parts of the room. Warm surfaces and larger doses are needed for bacteria to grow.
